translated: The Mansion on Display
The Divine Maiden’s Mansion🔽The Chapter about the Coral Tree
The Divine Maiden’s Mansion of Daddara🔽Shining with radiance,
and with fame, you outshine
all the gods in the Thirty-three.
You outshine them with your beauty.🔽I’ve never seen anyone like you before.
This is my first sight of you.
From what kind of person have you come
that you speak my name?”
“I was your Subhaddā, good lady,

original: pubbe mānusake bhave;🔽Sahabhariyā ca te āsiṁ,
analyzed: pubbe mānusake bhave  sahabhariyā ca te āsi
translated: in a previous human existence.
I was your wife and your younger sister.
When my body broke up,
I was released from that state and passed on.
I was reborn among the gods who delight in creating,
in the company of those gods.”
“Those who have done much good
go to the gods.
You will praise them,
Subhaddā, for your own birth.
But by what beauty,
by what instruction,
by what kind of generosity
are you so famous?
You have attained such fame
and have gone to a state of greatness.
Goddess, please tell me
What was the deed that led to this?”🔽“Eight alms-meals

analyzed: aṭṭha iva piṇḍapātāni  yam dānam adadam pure
translated: that I gave in the past,
to the Sangha of the worthy ones,
with my own hands, with confidence.
Because of that, I have such a complexion,

analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ ca me sabbadisā pabhāsati iti
translated: and my complexion shines in all directions.”

analyzed: aham tayā bahutare bhikkhū  saññate brahmacārayo
translated: “I gave to many more monks🔽who were restrained and lived the spiritual life
than you did,

analyzed: pasannā sehi pāṇibhi  tayā bahutaram da tvā
translated: with my own hands, with confidence.
Yet I was reborn in a lower realm.
How is it that you, giving to fewer,
have gone to a more distinguished and exalted place?
Goddess, please tell me this,
what was the deed that led to this?”
“A monk who was worthy of esteem
was seen by me in the past.
I invited him for a meal,
Revata, who was the best for me.
With my welfare in mind,

analyzed: anukampāya revato  saṅghe dehi iti mā avoca
translated: Revata, out of compassion,
told me to give to the Sangha. I did as he said.
That offering, given to the Sangha,
was established in the immeasurable.
What you gave to individuals
it will not be very fruitful for you.”
“Now I know
that what is given to the Saṅgha is very fruitful.
When I have gone to the human realm,
generous and free from stinginess,
I will give gifts to the Saṅgha,
mindful, again and again.”
“Which goddess are you, lovely one,

analyzed: tayā mantayate saha  sabbe deve tāvatise
translated: that you are consulting with?🔽You outshine in beauty
all the Thirty-Three gods.”
“I was a human, lord of the gods,

original: pubbe mānusake bhave;🔽Sahabhariyā ca me āsi,
analyzed: pubbe mānusake bhave  sahabhariyā ca me āsi
translated: in a previous human existence.🔽I was the wife of your brother,
your younger sister.
Having given gifts to the Saṅgha,
I shine, having made merit.”
“In accordance with the Teaching, your sister
shines, lovely one.
In the immeasurable Saṅgha
you established a gift.”
“When I asked the Buddha,
on the Vulture Peak,🔽about the result of sharing,

analyzed: yattha dinnam mahapphala  yajamānānam manussāna  puññapekkhāna pāṇina
translated: where what is given is very fruitful,🔽for people who sacrifice,🔽for living beings who seek merit,
who make merit with requisites,
where what is given is very fruitful.
The Buddha explained it to me,
knowing the fruit of his own deeds.
The result of sharing,
where what is given bears great fruit.
The four who are practicing,

original: cattāro ca phale ṭhitā;🔽Esa saṅgho ujubhūto,
analyzed: cattāraḥ ca phale ṭhitā  esa saṅghaḥ uju bhūtaḥ
translated: and the four who are established in the fruits,🔽This is the straight,
the Saṅgha that is intent on virtue and concentration.
For people who are sacrificing,🔽for living beings who desire merit,
who are making merit with requisites,
what is given to the Saṅgha bears great fruit.
This Saṅgha is vast and exalted,
immeasurable like the ocean.

analyzed: ete hi seṭṭhāḥ nara vīra sāvakā
translated: These are the best of the Buddha’s disciples,
the radiant ones who proclaim the Teaching.
What is well-given, well-offered, and well-sacrificed
to those who give gifts dedicated to the Saṅgha,
that offering is established in the Saṅgha,
having great fruit, praised by those who know the world.
Remembering such a sacrifice,
those who live in the world with awareness,
having removed the stain of selfishness,
go to heaven, to the deathless state.”
The Daddara peacock’s account is the sixth.
